column1:
0'6M4HKMU1E'Why I choose CRA ( Create-react-app) over Vite for this React project ?'"

You must have stumbled upon many posts praising Vite and how it should be the de-facto standard to get started with React apps. Vite is awesome
column2: nothing wrong with it. But
column3: sometimes I just believe when you're put into this decision-making situation
column4: you should give yourself some time instead of blindly picking the new tech upgrade in the market and ditching the older one.

column1: I still use both CRA (create-react-app) and Vite for my React projects. In the organization (Mercedes Benz) I work
column2: we had to start a new project from nothing. We had interns
column3: and junior developers to collaborate with on that project. The project requirements were mostly already defined and were not likely to change in a short period. It was established to be a small to medium-sized full-stack application with an estimated completion time of two months. There weren't major performance-related concerns so I decided to pick CRA even though I
column4: myself am a big admirer of Vite.

column1: CRA has been proven successful over these many years and got support from Facebook. It was easier to find help related to deployment
column2: installation of new packages and more issues in case they show up in the development process (which they would). It is not an app which is likely to be in the development phase for a long period. Had that been the case
column3: or we were likely to face performance-related issues in the long run because of the app being too bulky
column4: I'd have opted to go with Vite. But
column5: that wasn't the case here. Sticking with CRA ensures that we have more help available on the internet
column6: less time spent on learning and more in development. Most packages have stable compatible versions with CRA available with proper documentation. So

column1: I've seen some developers blindly going for the upgrades in the market instead of considering the older technology while making architectural-level decisions in designing an application from scratch. In my opinion
column2: it is completely fine to sometimes stick with older tech stack even while creating new applications. I'd bring Vue into the picture for a moment where there is a buzz in the market about why you should ditch Vue 2 ever since a stable version of Vue 3 has been released. But
column3: why always? Why can't I use Vue 2.6 in my apps in 2023? Maybe there is a UI library that only has a stable version for Vue 2. It is your choice to still use Vue 2 or create-react-app
column4: it is not obsolete and not likely to be so for the next few years. So relax
column5: and use what you love. You should however have a pretty convincing reason to justify your choice.

column2: that's it for this post. Here
column3: I just put my two cents on why it's fine to continue using existing technologies despite them having better upgrades available. If you have anything to say
column4:
please comment in the comments section. See you in the next post. üòÄ

column1:
1'1JN22FUIA'"3 Lesson I've From Spotlighting Women in tech"'"

You know how they say ""You learn as you go""? Well
column2: it's actually true. For March
column3: I decided to publish my series
column4: Bada$$ Women in Tech. It's where I write posts on Twitter about women who made wonderful contributions to the tech industry every day in honor of International Women's History Month. By shining a spotlight on some of the amazing women I‚Äôve worked with
column5: I‚Äôve not only been able to learn the diverse stories and triumphs of women in tech
column6: but I've learned 3 lessons on writing along the way. Now
column7: grab a your keyboard and open a new document on Google Docs(or whatever word processing system you use) because

column1: 1. You can contribute to tech in many ways.
When I started Bada$$ Women in Tech
column2: I initially was going to focus on women who are entrepreneurs
column3: CEOs
column4: and founders. As I found and researched more women to spotlight
column5: I quickly realized that whether they are CEO or community manager at a tech start-up
column6: any woman's story of contribution to the industry is important and must be shared. Ok onto the next lesson.

column1: I was brainstorming some names to add to my list of women to highlight
column2: and I came across this person:

column1: This Angelica Ross. She's known for playing Candy on Pose and runs a non-profit tech organization called TransTech Social Enterprise

column2: I was really excited about the idea of including her in my series but then I remembered that some parts of Twitter have bigoted views about transwomen
column3: so I experienced a little bit of mental ping-pong game. On one hand
column4: I wanted to share her story since my goal for this series was to celebrate women from diverse backgrounds in tech
column6: I did not want Ross and any other transwoman to be subjected to potential bullying and harassment. So I posted my concern on one of the Discord channels in Baddies in Tech (one of the greatest communities I've ever been in) and asked for some advice. A few minutes later
column7: one person mentioned that I was doing a good thing by adding Ross to my lineup and just simply block any Twitter trolls(To social media newbies
column8: trolls are individuals who often post negative comments under a person's post) from my thread. They also suggested that I post a link to my tweet so they can retweet it and defend my post against negative comments. So
column9: I took that person's advice and made that post. Ok
column11: so let's get back to the lessons before I start crying.

column2: two hands are actually better than one. Since I started this series
column3: I have received a lot of support and some suggestions from other women on ladies to spotlight in my series. This warmed my heart because it shows that my series' goal is being achieved: empowering women in the tech community.  Ok
column4: let's move on before I get emotional!

column2: I am very proud of starting this series
column3: and I look forward to seeing how many women I can empower as it continues to grow. Speaking for growth
column4: if you have any suggestions on what you would like to be spotlighted
column5: post them in the comments section below. Also
column6: don't forget to follow me on Twitter to see updates on my series and connect with me on my other socials via Linkfree. Now
column7: go out there be awesome ladies and those in between!

and Real-World Use Cases'"

As a developer coming from a Java background
column4: one of the first things I thought about when starting to work with Go was whether there was a similar concept to Filters that I had grown accustomed to. <strong>Fortunately
column5: Go has its own way of handling middleware
column6: and it's a powerful feature that can help you write better

column1: Middleware is a powerful concept in Go that allows you to intercept and modify HTTP requests and responses. It‚Äôs a way to add functionality to your HTTP server without modifying your core application logic. Middleware is essentially a chain of functions that can be executed before and after the main request handler. It can perform tasks like authentication
column2: logging
column3: request validation

column2: we‚Äôll explore the basics of middleware in Go and take a deep dive into some real-world use cases.

column1: Let‚Äôs understand first Why should we use Middleware in Go?

We should use middleware in Go because it provides a modular and extensible way to add functionality to our web application. Middleware sits between the incoming HTTP request and the application‚Äôs final response
column2: allowing us to add features like authentication
column3: request logging
column4: and error handling. By using middleware
column5: we can keep our application‚Äôs core logic clean and focused

column1: What principle will break if we don‚Äôt use middleware in Go?
If we don‚Äôt use middleware in Go
column2: we risk violating the single responsibility principle. This principle states that a module
column3: class
column4: or function should only have one reason to change. If we don‚Äôt use middleware
column5: we may be tempted to add features like authentication or request logging directly to our application‚Äôs request handlers. This can lead to bloated
column6: hard-to-maintain code that is difficult to change.

column1: Middleware is very helpful in scenarios where we need to perform common tasks on incoming HTTP requests
column2: such as authentication
column3: authorization
column5: and logging. Middleware allows us to apply these tasks consistently across our application
column6: reducing code duplication and making it easier to maintain and modify our code.

column1: What all middleware must we have in our code?
The middleware that we need in our code depends on the specific requirements of our application. However
column2: there are several middleware functions that are commonly used in web applications
column3: including:

column1: Authentication middleware: This middleware checks whether the user is authenticated and authorized to access the requested resource.
Logging middleware: This middleware logs information about incoming requests
column2: including request method
column3: URL

column1: Error handling middleware: This middleware catches errors that occur during request handling and returns an appropriate error response to the client.
Request validation middleware: This middleware validates incoming requests to ensure that they meet certain criteria
column2: such as HTTP method
column3: headers

column1: Caching middleware: This middleware caches responses to certain requests to improve performance and reduce server load.

Request Tracing: This middleware is used to trace the path of a request through a web application. It captures relevant information about the request and logs it for monitoring and debugging purposes.
The question that could be coming to your mind next is:
Go has a built-in net/http package that provides a basic HTTP server. To use middleware with this server
column2: we simply need to wrap the original handler with our middleware function.

column1: There are many third-party packages available that provide more advanced functionality. One of the most popular is Gin
column2: a web framework that provides a powerful set of tools for building web applications. We also use in our org gin Webframework.

column1: Gin uses a custom Context object instead of the http.ResponseWriter and *http.Request objects used in the standard net/http package. This Context object provides additional functionality and allows middleware functions to perform more advanced tasks.

column2: we can use the Use() method of the gin.Engine object. Here's an example of how we can add middleware to a Gin application:

r.Use(traceRequest)
r.Use(secureRequest)

column1: The order in which we add middleware using the Use() method matters. Middleware functions are executed in the order they are added
column2: so it's important to add them in the correct order to ensure that the desired behavior is achieved.

column2: you know how important it is to stay up-to-date with the latest language features and tools. That's why ES6 (also known as ECMAScript 2015) is such a game-changer. With its powerful new features and improved syntax
column3: ES6 has revolutionized modern JavaScript development. But with so many new additions to the language

column2: we'll walk you through the most essential ES6 features that every JavaScript developer should know. From block-scoped variables to template literals
column3: we'll show you how these features can make your code more concise
column5: and maintainable. So whether you're a seasoned JavaScript pro or just starting out
column6: get ready to take your skills to the next level with ES6!

column2: block-scoped variables can be declared using let and const keywords. Block-scoped variables are only accessible within the block of code they were defined in. This means that if a variable is declared inside a block of code
column3: it cannot be accessed outside that block. This feature of JavaScript allows developers to write more secure and predictable code
column4: reducing the chance of variable name collisions.

column1: The let keyword is used to declare block-scoped variables that can be reassigned later. In the following example
column2: we declare a variable x outside an if block and assign it the value 10. Inside the if block
column3: we declare another variable x and assign it the value 20. When we log the value of x inside the if block
column5: when we log the value of x outside the if block
column6: we get the value 10. This is because the variable x inside the if block is a different variable than the one declared outside the block.

column1: console.log(x); // Output: 20
console.log(x); // Output: 1
The const keyword is used to declare block-scoped variables that cannot be reassigned. In the following example
column2: we declare a constant PI and assign it the value 3.14159. When we try to reassign the value of PI to 42
column3: we get an error because we cannot reassign a constant.

column1: PI = 42; // Throws an error
Arrow functions are a new syntax for creating functions in JavaScript. They provide a concise way to define functions and are often used in conjunction with other new features of JavaScript like let
column2: const
column3: and template literals. Arrow functions have a shorter syntax than traditional functions and provide a few benefits over them.

column1: The syntax for an arrow function looks like this: (arguments) => { expression }. The arrow function can take zero or more arguments
column2: and the function body is a single expression. If the expression is a single statement
column3: it does not require curly braces.

column2: we define a traditional function add that takes two arguments and returns their sum. We then define an arrow function add that does the same thing. The arrow function is shorter and more concise than the traditional function.
b) {

column2: b) => a + b;

const sayHello = name => {

column2: ${name}!`;

column1: console.log(message);

Template literals are another new feature of JavaScript that allows developers to create strings more easily. They provide a way to include variables and expressions inside a string without having to concatenate them using the + operator. This makes code more readable and easier to write.
The syntax for a template literal is a string enclosed in backticks. Inside the string
column2: we can include variables or expressions by wrapping them in ${}. In the following example
column3: we define a variable name and a string message that includes the variable using a template literal. This is equivalent to concatenating the string using the + operator.

column1: const name = 'John';

column2: ${name}!`;

column1: console.log(message); // Output: ""Hello
column2: John!""

column1: We can also include expressions inside a template literal. In the following example
column2: we define two variables and use them in a template literal to create a string that calculates the sum of two numbers.

column1: const a = 10;
const sum = `${a} + ${b} = ${a + b}`;
console.log(sum); // Output: ""10 + 20 = 30""

column2: which can be useful when working with long strings of text. In the following example
column3: we define a variable that includes line breaks using a template literal.

column1: const text = `This is a
console.log(text); // Output: ""This is a\nmulti-line\nstring.""

Destructuring is a new feature of JavaScript that allows us to extract values from objects and arrays and assign them to variables. This can simplify code by reducing the need to write verbose code to access properties of objects or elements of arrays.

column2: we can use the following syntax:

column1: const¬†person = {¬†name:¬†'John'
column2: ¬†age:¬†30¬†};
age } = person;

we create an object called person with two properties: name and age. We then destructure the object using curly braces {} and assign the values of the name and age properties to variables of the same name. The resulting variables will have the values 'John' and 30
column3: respectively.

column2: we can use the following syntax:

column1: const¬†numbers = [1
column2: ¬†2
column3: ¬†3

column2: second
column3: ...rest] = numbers;

column2: we create an array called numbers with five elements. We then destructure the array by assigning the values of the first and second elements to variables called first and second
column3: respectively. We also use the rest parameter syntax ... to assign the remaining elements of the array to a new array called rest.

we've covered some of the most useful ES6 features that can make your JavaScript code more efficient
column3: readable
column4: and maintainable. From destructuring to arrow functions to classes

7'47VRKYVLY'"Building a Random Nerd Joke App with Public API's in Javascript ."'"

Javascript is a well loved & accepted Programming Language
column2: due to it‚Äôs synchrony with both client and server-side applications. and API‚Äôs are simply url‚Äôs that makes request to server  side & gets data & sending it back to client side. Here
column3: I made a simple web app that spits out nerdy jokes with liners & responses with the click of a button
column4: this was of course made possible with a free web API for random jokes i found on Github. So I Would like to show y‚Äôall how i made this fun project from scratch. With Steps and Code visualization of the processes.

column2: create a new folder for your project and open it in your favorite code editor. Then
column3: create a new HTML file called index.html and a new JavaScript file called main.js.

column2: you'll need to include the following scripts in your HTML file:
we're writing out client-side content with HTML and linking our main.js
column3: normalize.css
column4: rest.css & style.css file to our HTML file.

column2: you'll need to get an API key. There are several APIs available for jokes content
column3: so i found this one on a free API repo on Github . For this tutorial

column2: add your query selector for your button element with an event listener to response to clicks.
add a function that takes in your Event listener and API request
column3: Here i used a function name called ‚ÄúgetFetch‚Äù with an empty parameter because it is not needed in this case.

column1: <li>In The first line after your function
column2: create a variable that cannot be reassigned
column3: so as to hold your API Request URL link as stored data.

column2: to fetch data from the API URL by getting a parse response from the server-side and returning it back as JSON data
column3: the JSON data returned back is logged on the console with a ‚Äúthen‚Äù method to display object properties & methods for reference.

column1: • Add A ‚ÄúCatch‚Äù Error method on the next line and log it in the console to display error messages in your API Request/Response.
<li>Under your API Request response data logged into the console
column2: add your query selector to your ‚Äúh2‚Äù element which is the desired content text size in the html for the random joke liners
column3: with an inner-text method to enable it display the ‚Äú data.setup‚Äù JSON property in the API Response.

column1: <li>Add another  query selector to your ‚Äúh3‚Äù element which is the desired content text size in the html for the random joke punchliner response
column2: with an inner-text method to enable it display the ‚Äú data.punchline‚Äù JSON property in the API Response
column3: on the DOM.

column1: • Did a brief CSS Styling of the page to align the view in visual /UX coherence.
Now that we have the API response
column2: we need to display Joke liners & Responses.

column1: • click on the ‚Äú want Sum Random Nerd Jokes?‚Äù Button to generate random jokes with punchline responses which displays under the button .
• Have fun & smile through the jokes. lol.

So that‚Äôs It. this was something i did in a matter of minutes with my knowledge of how to integrate API‚Äôs in Javascript projects. I Hope this gave you some insight especially if you‚Äôre a newbie to Javascipt API‚Äôs & OOP‚Äôs. I‚Äôll be back with more fun projects.

column2: and its¬†Oh my fish¬†framework as my command line shell. Over the years
column3: I have gathered many useful functions and shortcuts. Here are my favorites.

column1: Let's start with some general shortcuts. The first one is the¬†brc¬†shortcut which reloads the¬†.bashrc¬†file and refreshes its content. That way
column2: I can use new shortcuts if added.

column1: alias brc=""source ~/.config/fish/.bashrc""
Since I am using VS Code Insiders
column2: whose command in the terminal is¬†code-insiders
column3: which I am too lazy to write every time

column1: alias ci=""code-insiders""
Sometimes I use¬†The Fuck¬†app for my terminal
column2: but it might be inconvenient when sharing screen. So
column3: I use a shortcut¬†pls¬†to run¬†fuck¬†command.

column1: Recently Josie posted on Twitter how she cannot remember how to add the SSH key.
""I have been a software engineer for 7 years and I will never remember the steps to adding a SSH key to my Github profile I'm so sorry.""
It reminded me of the SSH shortcuts that I configured many years ago. So here are my SSH shortcuts.

column2: I use the¬†sshkey¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the SSH user filename

column1: function sshAddKey  ssh-keygen -t rsa -C $argvendalias sshkey=sshAddKey
To start the SSH agent and add the SSH key
column2: I use the¬†sshuser¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the SSH user filename

column1: function sshStart  eval ssh-agent -s  ssh-add ~/.ssh/$argv[1]endalias sshuser=sshStart
To delete all identities from the agent
column2: I use the¬†sshdel¬†shortcut.

column1: alias sshdel=""ssh-add -D""
To test the SSH connection to GitHub
column2: I use the¬†sshpingg¬†shortcut.

column1: alias sshpingg=""ssh -T git@github.com""

column2: 11ty
column3: and custom Node.js scripts in my workflow
column4: I have situations where I need to kill a process or two that are stuck or hanging.

column1: To check if a process already occupies a port
column2: I use the¬†checkPort¬†shortcut with am additional argument
column3: the port

column1: function checkPort  lsof -t -i:$argv[1]endalias cport=checkPort
To terminate all processes that occupy a port
column2: I use the¬†kport¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the port

column1: function killPort  kill -9 (lsof -t -i:$argv[1])endalias kport=killPort

column2: I use the¬†killnode¬†shortcut.

column1: alias killnode=""killall -9 node""

column2: I use the¬†kf¬†shortcut.

column1: alias kf=""killify""
kf¬†is just an alias for¬†my killify NPM package.
For general filesystem navigation in my terminal
column2: I'm using¬†z¬†command. But for finer control
column3: I am using the following commands.

column2: I use¬†cd..¬†and¬†..¬†commands.

column1: alias cd..=""cd ..""alias ..=""cd ..""
To see the long listing format of the current folder
column2: I use the¬†ll¬†and¬†lll¬†shortcuts. To see every single file and folder within current folder
column3: I use the¬†llll¬†shortcut.

column1: alias ll=""ls -la""alias lll=""exa -abghHliS""function exaTree  exa --long --tree $argvendalias llll=exaTree

column2: I use the¬†rr¬†and¬†rrr¬†shortcuts. The difference is that the¬†rr¬†shortcut shows prompt before removal.

column1: alias rr=""rm -rf -i""alias rrr=""rm -rf""
Use¬†rm -rf¬†with extreme caution. The action cannot be reverted
column2: and all deleted files and folders are permanently gone.

column1: I am using a lot of Git shortcuts
column2: but here are my favorites.
I use the¬†gl¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gl=""git log --oneline --graph""

column2: removed
column3: or changed file in the current repository

column1: alias gs=""alias ga.=""git add .""

column2: I use the¬†gc¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the message

column1: # git: commit with messagefunction commitWithMessage  git commit -m $argvendalias gc=commitWithMessage

column2: I use the¬†gcam¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the new message

column1: # git: commit amend messagefunction commitAmend  git commit --amend -m $argvendalias gcam=commitAmend
Remember to add quotation marks when using the¬†gc¬†and¬†gcam¬†shortcuts.
To view all local and remote branches
column2: I use the¬†gba¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gba=""git branch -a""
To prune or to delete the refs to the branches that don't exist on the remote
column2: I use the¬†grpo¬†shortcut.

column1: function pruneOrigin  git remote prune origin  gbaendalias grpo=pruneOrigin

column2: I use the¬†gfa¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gfa=""git fetch --all""
To push all local branches to remote
column2: I use the¬†gpa¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gpa=""git push --all""

column2: I use the¬†gr¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gr=""git reset --hard""

column2: I use the¬†gcm¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gcm=""git checkout master""
To pull the master branch from the remote
column2: I use the¬†gpom¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gpom=""git pull origin master""

column2: I use the¬†gcn¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the branch name

column1: function checkoutNew  git checkout -b $argvendalias gcn=checkoutNew

column2: a set of Git extensions that makes it easier to implement¬†Vincent Driessen's branching model¬†I have used for ages.
I use the¬†gfi¬†shortcut.

column1: alias gfi=""git flow init""

column2: I use the¬†gfs¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the branch name

column1: function flowFeatureStart  git flow feature start $argvendalias gfs=flowFeatureStart
To close and merge a feature branch
column2: I use the¬†gff¬†shortcut with an additional argument
column3: the branch name

column1: function flowFeatureFinish  git flow feature finish $argvendalias gff=flowFeatureFinish
I use similar shortcuts to start and finish the¬†hotfix¬†and¬†release¬†branches.
If you want to see my complete fish configuration

column1: 10'PYP7MGRLY'Getting Started with Boto3: A Powerful and Versatile AWS SDK'"<h2>
AWS provides a variety of services that make it easy to build and manage applications in the cloud. One of the most powerful tools for interacting with AWS services is Boto3
column2: an AWS SDK for Python. Boto3 makes it easy to write Python scripts that automate tasks
column3: interact with AWS services
column4: and manage AWS resources. In this post
column5: we'll explore the basics of using Boto3 with AWS and see how it can be used to manage AWS resources effectively.

column1: Boto3 is a Python library that allows developers to write scripts to interact with AWS services. It provides a simple and easy-to-use API that can be used to perform common tasks such as creating and managing EC2 instances
column2: managing S3 buckets
column3: and managing AWS services. Boto3 is built on top of the AWS SDK for Python and is compatible with Python 2.6.x

column1: Boto3 provides a powerful set of tools for working with AWS. It is easy to use and offers a comprehensive set of APIs that can be used to automate tasks
column2: manage resources
column3: and interact with AWS services. Here are a few reasons why Boto3 is such a valuable tool:

column1: Versatile: Boto3 provides a versatile and powerful API that can be used to manage a wide variety of AWS services.
Easy to Use: Boto3 provides a simple and easy-to-use API that is easy to learn and use.
Comprehensive: Boto3 offers a comprehensive set of APIs that can be used to automate tasks
column2: manage resources
column3: and interact with AWS services.

column1: Pythonic: Boto3 is built on top of the AWS SDK for Python and provides a Pythonic interface that is easy to understand and use.

column2: you'll need to install it using pip.
you'll need to create an AWS IAM user with appropriate permissions. You'll then need to create an AWS access key ID and secret access key
column3: which you'll use to authenticate your requests.

column1: lets do it step by step :

column2: you can use Boto3 to interact with AWS services. Boto3 provides a variety of low-level and high-level interfaces for interacting with AWS services
column3: so you can choose the level of abstraction that's appropriate for your needs. For example
column4: you can use Boto3 to perform tasks such as:

column1: • Managing AWS services like Elastic Beanstalk and RDS
Here are a few examples of how you can use Boto3 to manage AWS resources:
This code snippet shows how to use Boto3 to launch an EC2 instance. The boto3.client('ec2') method is used to create a client object for the EC2 service. Then
column2: the run_instances method is used to launch an EC2 instance with the specified parameters
column3: such as the AMI ID
column6: and minimum and maximum count. The method returns a response object that contains information about the launched instance. Finally
column7: the print function is used to display the response object.

column1: Boto3 can also be used to upload a file to an S3 bucket:

column2: 'rb') as data:
Body=data)

column1: This Python code uploads a file to an S3 bucket using Boto3 library. First
column2: it creates an S3 resource object using Boto3 and specifies the bucket to upload the file to. Then
column3: it opens the file in binary mode and uses the put_object() method of the bucket object to upload the file to the specified key in the bucket.

column1: Boto3 can also be used to create a Lambda function:
This code uses Boto3 to create a new AWS Lambda function with specified configuration parameters
column2: including the function name
column3: runtime

column1: The create_function() method sends a request to AWS Lambda to create the function and returns a response containing information about the newly created function
column2: including its Amazon Resource Name (ARN) and other metadata.

column1: Boto3 is a powerful and versatile AWS SDK that provides an easy-to-use API for interacting with AWS services. With its comprehensive set of APIs and Pythonic interface
column2: Boto3 makes it easy to automate tasks
